review.title: Activity-Based Search for Black-Box Contraint-Programming Solvers
review.abstract: Robust search procedures are a central component in the design of black-box constraint-programming solvers. This paper proposes activity-based search, the idea of using the activity of variables during propagation to guide the search. Activity-based search was compared experimentally to impact-based search and the WDEG heuristics. Experimental results on a variety of benchmarks show that activity-based search is more robust than other heuristics and may produce significant improvements in performance.

sections.heading: 5.1 The Experimental Setting
sections.text: The configurations All experiments were performed on a Macbook Pro with a core i7 running MacOS 10.6.7 at 2.66 Ghz. Ibs, wdeg, and Abs were all implemented into the Comet system. Since the search algorithms are usually randomized, the empirical results are based on 50 runs and the tables report the average (µT) and standard deviation of runtimes in seconds. Unless otherwise stated, a time span of 5 minutes was used and running that was assigned a 300 runtime. The following parameter values were used for the experimental results: α = 8 in both Ibs and Abs, γ = 0.999 (slow aging), and δ = 20%. Experimental results on the sensitivities of these parameters are also reported. For each heuristics, the results are given for three strategies: no restarts (NR), fast restart (Z = 1.1), or slow restart (Z = 2).

sections.heading: 5.4 Some Behavioral Observations
sections.text: Figure 5 shows the behavior of Abs and Ibs on radiation # 9 among all three restart strategies. The x-axis is the runtime on a logarithmic scale and the y-axis is the objective value each time a new upper limit is found. The three red curves represent the performance of an activity-based search, while the three blue curves correspond to the impact-based search. What is striking here is the difference in behavior between the two searches. Abs quickly descends to the optimal solution and then spends the remaining time proving the optimality. Without restarts, the activity-based search achieves the optimum within 3 seconds. On restarts, it finds the optimal solution within one second, and the proof of the optimality is also faster. Ibs slowly reaches the optimal solution, but then quickly proves the optimality. Restarts have a negative effect on Ibs. We suspect that the reduction of the large domains may not be such a good indicator of progress, and the search for certain radiation frequencies may be set to only 9. In the relatively high level of the individual radiation figure 6, the radiation values are relatively interesting.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Robust search methods are a central component in the design of black box constraint programming solvers. In this paper, an activity-based search was proposed, which aims to use the activity of variables during propagation to guide the search. Variable activity is incremented each time the propagation step filters its domain and otherwise ages. A sampling method is used to initialize the variable activity before the search. Activity-based search was experimentally compared with Ib and wdeg heuristics based on a variety of benchmarks.The experimental results showed that Abs was significantly more robust than Ibs and Wdeg in these classes of benchmarks and often produced significant performance improvements.

referenceMentions.context: Impact-based search (Ibs) [10] is motivated by concepts found in MIP solvers such as strong branching and pseudo costs.
Subsequent work about solution counting can be seen as an alternative to impacts [8] that exploits the structure of CP constraints.
The weighted-degree heuristic (wdeg) [1] is a direct adaptation of the SAT heuristic Vsids[5] to CSPs that relies on information collected from failures to define the variable ordering.
The weighted-degree heuristic (wdeg) [1] is a direct adaptation of the SAT heuristic Vsids[5] to CSPs that relies on information collected from failures to define the variable ordering.
Moreover, if if a failure is discovered at the root node, singleton arc-consistency [9] has been established and the value is removed from the domain permanently.
Ibs, wdeg, and Abs were were all implemented in the Comet system [3].
The multi-knapsack and magic square problems both come from the Ibs paper [10].
The nurse rostering problem [11] originated from a mathematicalprogramming paper and constraint programming was shown to be a highly effective and scalable approach.
The radiation problem is taken from the 2008 MiniZinc challenge [6] and has also been heavily studied.
Multi-Knapsack This benchmark is from [10] and our implementation follows Refalo’s informal description.
The COP uses n global binary knapsack constraints (binaryKnapsackAtmost in Comet) based on the filtering algorithm in [13].

Magic Square This benchmark is also from [10] and the model is based on a direct algebraic encoding with 2 · n linear equations for the rows and columns (the square side is n), 2 linear equations for the diagonals, one alldifferent constraint (not enforcing domain consistency) for the entire square, 2 · n binary inequalities to order the elements in the diagonals, and two binary inequalities to order the top-left corner against the bottom-left and top-right corners.
Progressive Party The progressive party problem [12] is a constraint satisfaction problem featuring a mix of global constraint and has been used frequently for benchmarking CP, LS, and MIP solvers.
Nurse Rostering This benchmark is taken from [11] and is a rostering problem assigning nurses to infants in an hospital ward, while balancing the workload.
Note that the custom procedure in [11] relies on a dynamic-symmetry breaking on values and sophisticated variable/value ordering.
Radiation This last benchmark is a constrained optimization problem for radiation therapy taken from the 2008 MiniZinc challenge [6].
